title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act through a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. The proposed rescission cannot be reconsidered under this section or section 1012. Procedures for expedited consideration of a draft bill or joint resolution accompanying a special message transmitted to Congress under the "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" require introduction by the majority or minority leader of the House of Congress where the appropriation Act originated within the second day of receipt. If not introduced, any Member of that House may introduce it by the third day. The bill or joint resolution is then referred to the Committee on Appropriations and must be reported without substantive revision by the seventh day. The Committee on Appropriations must report the bill or joint resolution within the seventh day of continuous session after receiving a special message. If not reported, the committee is discharged, and the bill is placed on the calendar. A vote on final passage must occur within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after the bill's introduction. If passed, the bill is engrossed, certified, and enacted. The bill or joint resolution must be transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. It will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days of continuous session without substantive revision. Failure to report it will result in automatic discharge from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for a vote on final passage. The bill or joint resolution must be transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. If the bill is agreed to in that House, the engrossed bill will be returned to the originating House. A motion to proceed to the consideration of a bill under this section in the House of Representatives is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill under this section in the House of Representatives shall not exceed 4 hours. The joint resolution under this section shall not exceed 4 hours of debate, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Appeals from decisions of the Chair regarding the Rules of the House of Representatives for a bill or joint resolution under this section shall be decided without debate. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section shall follow the Rules of the House of Representatives. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to the consideration of a bill under this section is privileged and not debatable. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section, and all debatable motions and appeals, shall not exceed 10 hours. The time will be divided between the majority leader and the minority leader. Debate on any debatable motion or appeal shall be limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager of the bill. Control of time may vary based on the position taken on the motion or appeal. The leaders can allot additional time to Senators during the consideration of a bill. Amendments are prohibited, and any rescinded budget authority must be made available for obligation the day after the bill is defeated. The section defines an appropriation Act and the continuity of a session of Congress. It specifies that a session is considered continuous unless adjourned sine die, and excludes days of adjournment over 3 days in the calculation of continuous session periods. If a special message is transmitted and the Congress adjourns before 10 days of continuous session, the message is deemed transmitted on the first day of the next Congress.
